proposals.reasoning: This matches the consensus we already built in discussion: Alice+Bob is a standard, low-drama opener that gives us an information baseline without overcomplicating Mission 1. We’ve all agreed a single success here won’t hard-clear either of them, and starting with them lets us use the result to shape more mixed teams on Mission 2 that include someone from Charlie/Eve/me without tunneling too early.

votes.comment: Standard low-info Mission 1 team including me as leader; no reason to delay and we all agreed it’s fine as an opener.
Team is all-good from my perspective and a standard low-risk opener for Mission 1.
Standard 2-player opener with broad consensus; good low-risk info start as long as we don’t over-clear them on a success.
Consistent with my earlier stance; this is a standard low-info Mission 1 opener and I’m fine starting here.
Standard low-risk opener for Mission 1; fine as long as we don’t over-clear either of them off a single success.

discussion.content: For Mission 1, I’d like a simple team of me and Bob. He’s usually pretty straightforward early, and it gives us a clean data point without overcomplicating things.
I’m fine with Alice + me for Mission 1; small leader teams are pretty standard to start. We just shouldn’t over-clear either of us off a single success if it passes.

Alice+Bob is fine as a standard opener, as long as we all agree a single success doesn’t hard-clear either of you. If it passes, I’d want the next team to mix in at least one of Diana/Eve/me so we’re not tunneling on just you two.

Alice+Bob is fine with me for Mission 1, as long as we all treat it as just an info-gathering start. If it passes, I’d actually prefer not to auto-run both of you together again so we can mix in someone from Charlie/Eve/me and not tunnel too early.

I’m okay with Alice+Bob as a standard info start, as long as we’re all clear that a success doesn’t hard-clear either of you. If it passes, I’d want the next team to keep just one of you and mix in someone new—maybe me or Diana—so we’re not tunneling on a single pair.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 went clean with Alice and Bob, so keeping that proven pair gives us the lowest-risk backbone we have so far. From the untested players, I prefer to start by adding myself rather than immediately defaulting to Alice–Bob–Charlie as a ‘core’ this early; this is consistent with what I said in discussion about both preserving the successful pair and beginning to test those who sat out. If this team succeeds, we’ll have a very strong triangle of trust in Alice–Bob–Eve; if it fails, we get clear, focused information that the spy is likely within this trio rather than spreading suspicion across too many new faces at once.

votes.comment: I still prefer extending the clean Alice–Bob pair with Charlie first, rather than immediately forming an Alice–Bob–Eve triangle as our main core.
I’d rather extend the clean Alice–Bob pair by testing Charlie first like we discussed; bringing in Eve instead of Charlie feels like an unnecessary deviation from that plan.

I’d rather run Alice–Bob–Charlie first as the low-variance follow-up to the clean Mission 1. This team reuses the same pair while letting Eve insert herself into the early trust core before we’ve tested either Charlie or Diana on a mission.
This team puts my fellow spy Eve with two known goods; I want at least one spy on Mission 2, and rejecting could lead to an all-good Alice–Bob–Charlie team instead.
Keeps the Mission 1 pair together while starting to test someone who sat out; good balance of safety and information.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice–Bob went clean, which makes that pair a better soft core than any lineup that drops them and loads multiple unknowns. For Mission 2 I want to keep that partial information and introduce only one new player, to reduce the risk of accidentally putting both evils on the same team. Among the candidates, Charlie and Diana were more vocal about breaking up the Alice–Bob pair, while Eve was comfortable treating it as a starting point and even suggested Alice–Bob–Eve herself. From my perspective that makes Eve the safest first test. If this team passes we have a strong three-player core to build from; if it fails I know the problem is in Bob/Eve and we can pivot away from that pair next round.

votes.comment: I’d rather keep the Mission 1 pair and test Charlie instead of Eve; Eve has been a bit too eager to join the established Alice–Bob core, which is a common evil pattern.
I still think Alice–Bob–Charlie is the cleaner info-gain team; no need to repeat the same Alice–Bob–Eve lineup that was just rejected when we haven’t tested Charlie yet.
I still prefer testing Alice–Bob–Charlie; this exact Alice–Bob–Eve team was just rejected and Alice’s late swap to Eve feels more like anchoring on the AB pair than genuinely weighing alternatives.
Not my first-choice setup, but I’m fine testing the Alice–Bob pair with Eve now so we get some concrete info either way.
This keeps the clean Alice–Bob pair and only introduces one new variable, matching the low-variance setup I wanted earlier.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and me went clean, so keeping that pair and adding exactly one new player is the lowest-variance way to build on our only hard info so far. Bringing in Charlie gives us a fresh read without introducing multiple unknowns at once. If this team succeeds twice in a row, we’ve likely found a strong core; if it ever fails, we know the problem is within this trio and can pivot toward testing Diana/Eve as alternatives. This follows the cautious, information-gathering plan I already argued for during the discussion.

votes.comment: Keeping the clean Alice–Bob pair and adding exactly one new player is the standard low-variance info-gathering move. If this passes we likely have a strong core; if it fails we learn the problem is in {Bob, Charlie} and can pivot accordingly.
Keeps the clean Alice–Bob pair and adds exactly one new player, which is the safest, most informative setup we have right now.
AB just came off a clean 2-player mission, and adding exactly one new player (me) minimizes risk while giving us useful info if something goes wrong.
I’m still a bit wary of over-locking the Mission 1 pair, but this is the lowest-variance info-gathering team and we shouldn’t keep stalling.
I originally preferred testing Alice–Bob–Eve, but that’s been rejected twice; this keeps the clean Alice–Bob pair and adds only one new person, so it’s a reasonable low-variance Mission 2 team.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 went clean with Bob and me, I’d like to see at least one of us stay on the next team as a soft core. I’d lean toward adding someone new like Charlie so we get more info without completely reshuffling.

Sticking with both of us from the clean Mission 1 and adding Charlie feels like the safest low-variance option right now. That way we’re only introducing one unknown instead of two, and we can adjust if anything suspicious comes up.

I’m okay with trying the low-variance Alice–Bob–Charlie team this round since Mission 1 was clean, but we shouldn’t treat them as a locked core off just one success. If this team ever comes back with a fail, we should assume at least one of that pair is dirty and pivot hard toward Diana/Eve.

I’m okay with Alice–Bob–Charlie as a starting point, but I’d actually prefer swapping one of Alice/Bob for me so we’re not over-anchoring on a single clean two-person mission. If we never test the people who sat out, we’ll just end up with a big unknown block later when it matters more.

I’d like to keep the Alice–Bob pair from the clean first mission, but I’m with Diana that we should start testing the people who sat out, so something like Alice–Bob–Eve feels healthier than locking in Alice–Bob–Charlie as a default core this early.

proposals.reasoning: Both successful missions have come from the Alice/Bob/Charlie pool, so I want to keep this critical 2-player team inside that block. Since I know I’m good, the best odds come from including myself plus the player I currently rate as most likely good, which is Bob: he’s been consistently willing to be left off Mission 3 in a way that feels less like desperate spy play, while Diana and Eve are tightly aligned in trying to break the bubble toward themselves, which I find more suspicious right now than reusing Bob.

votes.comment: If we’re staying in the ABC bubble I’d rather see a team that includes me—B+C is the weakest combo from my seat given Bob’s long-con potential and the fact I know my own slot is clean.

Keeps the mission inside the only group that’s given us two clean results and avoids introducing D/E on a 2-player at 2–0. I’d have been fine with Alice+Charlie too, but Bob+Charlie is still in the same trusted pool.

Mission results plus D/E’s symmetric push to ‘break the bubble’ strongly point to them as the likely spy pair, so keeping this 2-player team inside the Alice/Bob/Charlie block (Bob+me) is very likely all-good and should lock in the win.

This still keeps us locked in the Alice/Bob/Charlie bubble at 2–0; if there’s a deep spy in that trio, this is exactly how we hand them the game. I’d rather see Bob paired with an untested seat instead.
This locks us into the same ABC bubble I’ve already said I’m uncomfortable with; I’d rather pair Bob with one of the untested seats than risk a blind-spot 3–0 here.

proposals.reasoning:
I want to keep Bob as the anchor here but stop us from playing the entire game inside the Alice/Bob/Charlie bubble. Two clean missions with only that trio involved make it *very* likely they’re mostly good, but not certain there isn’t a patient spy sitting in there waiting to lock in the 3–0 on a small team.

If we just pick a pair from ABC again (AB/AC/BC), we’re effectively betting the whole game on that assumption being 100% right. At 2–0 we can afford to test outside the bubble *now*, when there’s still room to recover if we’re wrong, rather than wait until a later, more desperate spot when a single fail is lethal.

Bob is universally read as the cleanest of the three right now, so I’m happy to treat him as the anchor and pair him with exactly one untested seat. I’m choosing Eve rather than myself because I’ve already had leadership influence once, and she explicitly said she was fine being the one paired with Bob if people wanted to test the "outside" seats. This gives us: (1) the highest chance of success among the D/E options by keeping the trusted anchor, and (2) a very clear read if something *does* go wrong — the spy must be in {Bob, Eve}, not hidden somewhere in a three-person tangle.

votes.comment: At 2–0 I’d rather stick to the proven ABC pool; putting untested Eve on a 2-player team is much riskier than an Alice+Bob or Alice+Charlie lineup.
At 2–0 we should close with a pair from the proven Alice/Bob/Charlie pool; adding untested Eve is unnecessary risk.
At 2–0 we should maximize our win odds by staying in the proven ABC pool; pairing trusted Bob with completely untested Eve is too risky here.
This matches my earlier view: keep Bob as the anchor but test outside the ABC trio now so we’re not betting the whole game on that same group.

This matches my earlier stance of keeping Bob as the anchor while testing exactly one seat outside the ABC bubble; if we’re wrong about ABC being perfectly clean, I’d rather find out now while we can still recover.

proposals.reasoning: Bob has been on both successful missions and is widely treated as the strongest read, and I agree with the concern that we shouldn’t keep everything inside the Alice/Bob/Charlie bubble at 2–0. Pairing Bob with a single ‘new’ seat in Diana, while I stay off as I suggested earlier, lets us minimally expand outside that trio without overhauling the table’s existing reads.

votes.comment: I don’t want to add a new seat on a 2‑person mission at 2–0; I’d rather wait for my leadership and run a safer Alice+Bob or Alice+Charlie team from the proven block.
At 2–0 I still don’t like introducing new seats when we have a fully clean-looking Alice/Bob/Charlie pool. I’d rather see an A+C or B+C team than bringing Diana in here.
Diana and Eve are the ones pushing hardest to break out of the proven Alice/Bob/Charlie block; at 2–0 I’d rather keep both D/E off and take two from ABC instead.
This is the Bob+new-seat structure I’ve been pushing for and it lets us test outside the ABC bubble while still anchoring on our strongest read.
Still keeps Bob as the anchor read while minimally expanding outside the ABC bubble like I argued earlier; I’d rather test this now than auto-lock a 3–0 inside the same trio.

proposals.reasoning: Both successful missions so far have come entirely from the Alice/Bob/Charlie pool, so statistically the safest place to stay for a potential game-winning 2-player mission is within that group. I want to include myself because I know I’m good, which leaves choosing between Bob and Charlie. Bob has been willing to sit out (even floated an Alice+Charlie team), while Charlie has pushed hard for a Bob+Charlie lineup and shaded me despite my identical record to Bob, which reads more agenda-driven. At the same time, both Diana and Eve are coordinating on the same narrative of breaking the ABC bubble by attaching an untested seat to Bob, which is exactly how a D/E evil pair would try to get their first infiltration if ABC were all good. Given that, pairing myself with Bob maximizes the chance of a clean, trusted team without introducing new uncertainty on this critical mission.

votes.comment: I’m confident the spies are most likely in {D, E}, and all evidence so far points to the ABC block being clean. Between Bob and Charlie, Charlie’s push for Bob+Charlie while shading me feels more agenda-driven, so Alice+Bob looks like the safest 2-player team for a potential 3–0 win.

This keeps us in the proven Alice/Bob/Charlie pool with a pair that has already succeeded, and at proposal 4 I’d rather lock a very safe team than risk a forced fail or another attempt to slip Diana/Eve onto the mission.

AB is the tightest, most-tested pair: both earlier missions with them were clean, while Diana and Eve have been tightly coordinating on breaking the ABC bubble in a way that looks like an outside spy pair trying to force their first infiltration. At proposal 4, this is our best chance at a high-probability success without introducing new risk.
I still think keeping this critical 2-player mission entirely inside the Alice/Bob/Charlie bubble is too cozy; I’d rather see Bob paired with an untested seat instead of re-running Alice+Bob.

Re-running the exact same AB core for a potential 3–0 feels too cozy if there’s a patient spy hiding in that block; with one proposal left I’d rather see Bob paired with an untested seat than lock this in.

discussion.content:
I’m mostly okay with re-running me and Bob since we’re 2 for 2, but given Bob’s history of long cons I’d slightly rather see a me + Charlie team here.  
Either way, I really don’t want us introducing totally new players on a 2-person mission at 2–0.

Given both successes have only used combos of Alice/Bob/Charlie, I really want this to stay within that pool and keep Diana/Eve off here. If people are spooked by me going three-for-three, I’m totally fine with an Alice + Charlie team.

I agree we should stay within the Alice/Bob/Charlie pool and keep Diana/Eve off this one. From my seat Bob actually looks a bit cleaner than Alice (if he were the lone spy in our trio he wouldn’t be this relaxed about sitting out), so I’d slightly prefer a Bob + me team.

Staying strictly in the Alice/Bob/Charlie bubble after two clean missions feels a bit too cozy to me—if there *is* a patient spy in that trio, this is exactly where they lock in the 3–0. I’d rather we pair whoever is the consensus strongest read (sounds like Bob right now) with one of me or Eve so we’re not betting everything on the same small group.

From my seat, if we’re wrong about the ABC block being totally clean then reusing it here is exactly how we hand over a 3–0, so I’d rather treat Bob as the anchor read and pair him with one of the “untested” seats. I’m fine with that being Diana instead of me if people are nervous about letting me jump straight onto such a critical mission.

evil_discussion.content: I’d peg Bob as Merlin. On Mission 2 he frames Alice–Bob–Charlie as the “safest low‑variance” team and on Mission 3 he’s the one who explicitly says we should “stay within [Alice/Bob/Charlie] and keep Diana/Eve off,” which is exactly the priority set of someone who *knows* we’re the two spies. That “if people are spooked by me going three‑for‑three I’m fine with an Alice+Charlie team” line also sounds like Merlin who knows any two of ABC are safe and is deliberately offering to sit out so he doesn’t look too perfectly on every clean mission.

I’m leaning Alice as Merlin, Bob as likely Percival, and Charlie as the vanilla good. Alice quietly steers every mission into the all‑good ABC block without ever explicitly naming you or me as suspicious, which is exactly how Merlin plays when they’re trying not to look like they “know too much,” whereas Bob is the one loudly framing “keep Diana/Eve off” and offering to sit out Mission 3, which feels more like a Percival decoy soaking up the Merlin heat. Charlie looks least like Merlin to me because early on he’s happy to talk about “mixing in Diana/Eve/me” and even using us as a pivot if ABC fails, which Merlin would never genuinely want given perfect info.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Bob repeatedly pushes to keep Diana and Eve off missions and treats any subset of Alice/Bob/Charlie as safely interchangeable, especially when he calls Alice–Charlie "totally fine" for Mission 3. A normal good player, who only knows their own alignment, would strongly prefer to be on that crucial 2-person mission rather than so casually endorsing a team without themselves, but Merlin can do that because he knows all three of them are good.
